senses.sense: (informal) Clipping of operation.
examples: My mother's going in for her knee op today.

senses.sense: (informal) Clipping of operator.
(informal) An amateur radio operator.
(internet) An operator on IRC, who can moderate the chat channel, ban users, etc.
(internet slang, chiefly plural) Clipping of opinion.
examples: Ops on my new drawing?

senses.sense: (mostly attributive) Ellipsis of op art
examples: an op painting; op artworks

senses.sense: (transitive, Internet) To promote (an IRC user) to an operator.
(internet slang) Alternative letter-case form of OP ("original post, original poster").
(slang, among criminal gangs) Alternative form of opp ("opponent; opposition").
(AU, informal, transitive) To buy (something) from an op shop.
(AU, informal, intransitive) To shop at op shops.
(obsolete) To darken; to cloud.
The action of making something opaque or cloudy
simple past tense and past participle of opacify
(chemistry) a chemical agent added to a material, such as rocket propellant, to make it opaque
(figuratively) an extraneous agent or vehicle which, intentionally otherwise, makes something opaque
third-person singular simple present indicative form of opacify
(transitive) To make opaque.
present participle of opacify
Any instrument that measures opacity
(geology) A small, dark grain, of doubtful origin, in an igneous rock
plural of opacity
(uncountable) The state or quality of being opaque, not allowing light to pass through
examples: We could not see the sandbar due to the opacity of the muddy water.

senses.sense: (uncountable) The state or quality of being inaccessible to understanding.
examples: The opacity of these decisions is troubling.

senses.sense: (optics, countable) A measure of relative impenetrability to electromagnetic radiation such as light.
examples: The opacity of a clean glass window is near zero.

senses.sense: (obsolete, chiefly poetic) Not shining or illuminated; dark.
(obsolete) Not allowing the passage of light; opaque.
(obsolete) Opacity.
Any of various large, colourful, deep-bodied pelagic fish of the family Lamprididae.
plural of opah
(mineral) A mineral consisting, like quartz, of silica, but inferior to quartz in hardness and specific gravity, of the chemical formula SiO<sub>2</sub>·nH<sub>2</sub>O.
(gemology) A precious gem, an iridescent gemstone found in the opal-silica mineral substrate (potch)
(biology, genetics, biochemistry) A colloquial name used in molecular biology referring to a particular stop codon sequence, "UGA."
Any of various lycaenid butterflies of the genus Nesolycaena.
(poetic) opalescent; misty or milky in appearance
To be opalescent; to give forth a play of colours, like the opal.
simple past tense and past participle of opalesce
the state of being opalescent

(physics) the milky iridescent appearance of a dense transparent medium when it is illuminated by polychromatic visible radiation (such as sunlight) due to local fluctuations in its density and therefore in its refractive index
Exhibiting a milky iridescence like that of an opal.
third-person singular simple present indicative form of opalesce
present participle of opalesce
Similar to opal; having some of the qualities of opal.
A fish, Girella nigricans.
Resembling opal in having a milky white iridescence.
A clear to white liquid secreted by sea hares (genus Aplysia) that becomes viscous upon contact with water.
examples: The attack on a sea hare by a spiny lobster causes release of the whitish opaline, followed the co-release of both opaline and ink.

senses.sense: (mineral) Any of several minerals resembling opal, including a variety of yellow chalcedony.
Synonym of opal glass
plural of opaline
(zoology) Any heterokont in the family Opalinidae.
Resembling or characteristic of opal.

(transitive) To make opalescent.

Converted into a form of opal or chalcedony
present participle of opalize
(dated) A photograph taken on opalescent glass.
plural of opal
Neither reflecting nor emitting light.
Allowing little light to pass through, not translucent or transparent.
(figuratively) Unclear, unintelligible, hard to get or explain the meaning of.
(figuratively) Obtuse, stupid.
(computing) Describes a type for which higher-level callers have no knowledge of data values or their representations; all operations are carried out by the type's defined abstract operators.
(obsolete, poetic) An area of darkness; a place or region with no light.
Something which is opaque rather than translucent.
(transitive) To make, render (more) opaque.
simple past tense and past participle of opaque
In an opaque manner.
The characteristic of being opaque.
comparative form of opaque: more opaque

superlative form of opaque: most opaque

(computing) A mnemonic used to refer to a microprocessor instruction in assembly language.
(mineral) A charnockitic form of granodiorite
(Cornish) alley or narrow passage e.g. Tonkin's Ope
(Midwest) an exclamation of surprise; oops
examples: Ope! Sorry about that.

senses.sense: (now dialectal or poetic) Open.
(archaic, ambitransitive) To open.
simple past tense and past participle of ope

An instrument, consisting of a tube with one end open and the other end covered with a thin flexible membrane with a mirror attached to its centre, used for exhibiting upon a screen, by means of rays reflected from the mirror, the vibratory motions caused by sounds that enter the tube.
A bright-coloured European actinian (Anemonia or Anthea sulcata).
(usually not comparable) Not closed.
Able to be accessed (physically).
Able to have something pass through or along it.
examples: Turn left after the second open door.

senses.sense: (of a body part) not covered, showing what is inside
examples: It was as if his body had gone to sleep standing up and with his eyes open.

senses.sense: Not physically drawn together, closed, folded or contracted; extended.
examples: an open hand; an open flower

senses.sense: (not comparable) Actively conducting or prepared to conduct business.
examples: Banks are not open on bank holidays.

senses.sense: (comparable) Receptive.
examples: I am open to new ideas.

senses.sense: (not comparable) Public
examples: He published an open letter to the governor on a full page of the New York Times.

senses.sense: (not comparable) With open access, of open science, or both.
examples: hopes for all aspects of the project being open rather than paywalled

senses.sense: (not comparable) Candid, ingenuous, not subtle in character.
examples: The man is an open book.

senses.sense: (now regional) Mild (of the weather); free from frost or snow.
(mathematics, logic, of a formula) Having a free variable.
(mathematics, topology, of a set) Which is part of a predefined collection of subsets of <math>X</math>, that defines a topological space on <math>X</math>.
(graph theory, of a walk) Whose first and last vertices are different.
(computing, not comparable, of a file, document, etc.) In current use; mapped to part of memory.
examples: I couldn't save my changes because another user had the same file open.

senses.sense: (engineering, gas and liquid flow, of valve or damper) To be in a position allowing fluid to flow.
(electricity, of a switch or circuit breaker) To be in a position preventing electricity from flowing.
(business) Not fulfilled.
examples: I've got open orders for as many containers of red durum as you can get me.

senses.sense: Not settled or adjusted; not decided or determined; not closed or withdrawn from consideration.
examples: an open question
to keep an offer or opportunity open
your account will remain open until we receive final settlement.

senses.sense: (music, stringed instruments) Of a note, played without pressing the string against the fingerboard.
(wind instruments) Of a note, played without closing any finger-hole, key or valve.
Not of a quality to prevent communication, as by closing waterways, blocking roads, etc.; hence, not frosty or inclement; mild; used of the weather or the climate.
examples: an open winter

senses.sense: (law, of correspondence) Written or sent with the intention that it may made public or referred to at any trial, rather than by way of confidential private negotiation for a settlement.
examples: You will observe that this is an open letter and we reserve the right to mention it to the judge should the matter come to trial.

senses.sense: (phonetics) Uttered with a relatively wide opening of the articulating organs; said of vowels.
(phonetics) Uttered, as a consonant, with the oral passage simply narrowed without closure.
(phonetics, of a syllable) That ends in a vowel; not having a coda.
(computing, education) Made public, usable with a free licence and without proprietary components.
(medicine) Resulting from an incision, puncture or any other process by which the skin no longer protects an internal part of the body.
(computing, used before "code") Source code of a computer program that is not within the text of a macro being generated.
(of a multi-word compound) Having component words separated by spaces, as opposed to being joined together or hyphenated; for example, time slot as opposed to timeslot or time-slot.
(transitive) To make something accessible or allow for passage by moving from a shut position.
examples: Turn the doorknob to open the door.

senses.sense: (transitive) To make (an open space, etc.) by clearing away an obstacle or obstacles, in order to allow for passage, access, or visibility.
examples: He opened a path through the undergrowth.

senses.sense: (transitive, intransitive, engineering, gas and liquid flow, of valve or damper) To move to a position allowing fluid to flow.
(transitive, intransitive, electricity, of a switch, fuse or circuit breaker) To move to a position preventing electricity from flowing.
(Manglish, Philippines) To turn on; to switch on.
examples: Open your webcam. ― Turn on your webcam.
Open the fan please. ― Please switch on the fan.
Open the lights please. ― Please turn on the lights.

senses.sense: (transitive) To bring up, broach.
examples: I don't want to open that subject.

senses.sense: (transitive) To enter upon, begin.
examples: to open a discussion
to open fire upon an enemy
to open trade, or correspondence
to open a case in court, or a meeting

senses.sense: (transitive) To spread; to expand into an open or loose position.
examples: to open a closed fist
to open matted cotton by separating the fibres
to open a map, book, or scroll

senses.sense: (transitive) To make accessible to customers or clients.
examples: I will open the shop an hour early tomorrow.

senses.sense: (transitive) To start (a campaign).
examples: Vermont will open elk hunting season next week.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To become open.
examples: The door opened all by itself.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To begin conducting business.
examples: The shop opens at 9:00.

senses.sense: (intransitive, cricket) To begin a side's innings as one of the first two batsmen.
(intransitive, poker) To bet before any other player has in a particular betting round in a game of poker.
examples: After the first two players fold, Julie opens for $5.

senses.sense: (transitive, intransitive, poker) To reveal one's hand.
examples: Jeff opens his hand revealing a straight flush.

senses.sense: (computing, transitive, intransitive, of a file, document, etc.) To load into memory for viewing or editing.
(transitive, nursing) To make (a bed) ready for a patient by folding back the bedcovers.
(obsolete) To disclose; to reveal; to interpret; to explain.
(with the) Open or unobstructed space; an exposed location.
examples: I can't believe you left the lawnmower out in the open when you knew it was going to rain this afternoon!
Wary of hunters, the fleeing deer kept well out of the open, dodging instead from thicket to thicket.

senses.sense: (with the) Public knowledge or scrutiny; full view.
examples: We have got to bring this company's corrupt business practices into the open.

senses.sense: (electronics) A defect in an electrical circuit preventing current from flowing.
examples: The electrician found the open in the circuit after a few minutes of testing.

senses.sense: A sports event in which anybody can compete.
examples: the Australian Open

senses.sense: The act of something being opened, such as an e-mail message.
The quality of being openable.
Capable of being opened.
(textiles, of a twist) Right-handed or "Z shaped", with individual fibers pointing up and to the right when the thread, yarn, or rope is vertical.
Either of two species of bird in the genus Anastomus of the stork family Ciconiidae, with a distinctive gap between the mandibles of the closed bill.
(chiefly British) Of or pertaining to strip mining, in which material is removed from a surface that has been exposed
simple past tense and past participle of open
A person who opens something.
A device that opens something; specifically a tin-opener/can-opener, or a bottle opener.
(in combination) An establishment that opens.
examples: The late-night openers in the mall include two restaurants and a clothing store.

senses.sense: (card games) The player who starts the betting.
(card games, in the plural) Cards of sufficient value to enable a player to open the betting.
(metalworking) A person employed to separate sheets of hot metal that become stuck together.
(theater) The first act in a variety show or concert.
(cricket) A batsman who normally plays in the first two positions of an innings.
(colloquial) The first in a series of events, items etc.; the first remark or sentence of a conversation.
(sports) The first game played in a competition.
(sports) The first goal or point scored.
(fishing) A period of time when it is legal to commercially fish.
(baseball) A pitcher who specializes in getting the first outs of a game before being replaced, either by a long reliever or a pitcher who would normally start.
plural of opener
(archaic) second-person singular simple present form of open
Alternative form of open-handed
Done with an open hand.
Generous.
Frank and tolerant.
Loose and full.
Alternative form of open-handed
With an open hand or hands.
Generously.
simple past tense and past participle of openhand
Alternative form of open-handedly
Alternative form of open-handedness
Alternative form of open-hearted
Alternative form of open-heartedly
Alternative form of open-heartedness
present participle of open
Pertaining to the start or beginning of a series of events.
examples: The opening theme of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony is, perhaps, the most recognizable in all of European art music.

The opening act of the battle for Fort Sumter was the firing of a single 10-inch mortar round from Fort Johnson at 4:30 a.m. on April 12, 1861, by Lt. Henry S. Farley, who acted upon the command of Capt. George S. James, which round exploded over Fort Sumter as a signal to open the general bombardment from 43 guns and mortars at Fort Moultrie, Fort Johnson, the floating battery, and Cummings Point.

senses.sense: (cricket) describing the first period of play, usually up to the fall of the first wicket; describing a batsman who opens the innings or a bowler who opens the attack
An act or instance of making or becoming open.
examples: The daily openings of the day lily bloom gives it its name.
He remembered fondly the Christmas morning opening of presents.

senses.sense: A gap permitting passage through.
examples: A salamander darted out of an opening in the rocks.
He slipped through an opening in the crowd.

senses.sense: An act or instance of beginning.
examples: There have been few factory and store openings in the US lately.
Their opening of the concert with Brass in Pocket always fires up the crowd.

senses.sense: Something that is a beginning.
The first performance of a show or play by a particular troupe.
examples: They were disappointed at the turnout for their opening, but hoped that word would spread.

senses.sense: The initial period when a show at an art gallery or museum is first opened, especially the first evening.
The first few measures of a musical composition.
The first few moves in a game.
examples: John spends two hours a day studying chess openings, and another two hours studying endgames.

senses.sense: A vacant position, especially in an array.
examples: Are there likely to be any openings on the Supreme Court in the next four years?

senses.sense: A time available in a schedule.
examples: If you'd like to make a booking with us, we have an opening at twelve o'clock.
The only two-hour openings for the hockey rink are between 1AM and 5AM.

senses.sense: An unoccupied employment position.
examples: We have an opening in our marketing department.

senses.sense: An opportunity, as in a competitive activity.
(math) In mathematical morphology, the dilation of the erosion of a set.
plural of opening
In an open manner, visibly, not covertly.
Alternative form of open-mouthed
With the mouth open, especially in astonishment.
Accommodating attitude or opinion, as in receptivity to new ideas, behaviors, cultures, peoples, environments, experiences, etc., different from the familiar, conventional, traditional, or one's own.
The degree to which a person, group, organization, institution, or society exhibits this liberal attitude or opinion.
Lack of secrecy; candour, transparency.

(computing, education) degree of accessibility to view, use, and modify in a shared environment with legal rights generally held in common and preventing proprietary restrictions on the right of others to continue viewing, using, modifying and sharing.
(systems theory) The degree to which a system operates with distinct boundaries across which exchange occurs capable of inducing change in the system while maintaining the boundaries themselves.
plural of openness
plural of open
third-person singular simple present indicative form of open
(rugby) The space on the side of the pitch with the larger distance between the breakdown/set piece and the touchline.
(rugby union) Short for openside flanker.
examples: The openside packs down at the scrum on the openside.

senses.sense: Any of several forms of metalwork or needlework having decorative openings.
(mining) A quarry; an open cut.
plural of openwork
(music) A theatrical work, combining drama, music, song and sometimes dance.
(music) The score for such a work.
A building designed for the performance of such works; an opera house.
A company dedicated to performing such works.
(by extension) Any showy, melodramatic or unrealistic production resembling an opera.
plural of opus; a collection of work.
plural of operability
The extent to which a system or device is operable.
Able to be operated or used
Able to be put into operation; practicable
Able to be treated by surgery
(medicine) Such that it allows an operation to take place.
Someone who attends an opera performance
(archaic) An instrument or machine for measuring work done, especially the number of rotations by a machine or wheel in manufacturing cloth.
The act of operating or working; operation.
(mathematics, computing) A quantity to which an operator is applied (in <math>3 - x</math>, the operands of the subtraction operator are 3 and <math>x</math>).
plural of operand
That operates to produce an effect.
examples: thy most operant poison

senses.sense: An operative person or thing.
(psychology) Any of a class of behaviors that produce consequences by operating (i.e., acting) upon the environment.
In an operant manner

plural of opera
Alternative form of operable
(transitive or intransitive) To perform a work or labour; to exert power or strength, physical or mechanical; to act.
examples: Could someone explain how this meeting operates?
In this town, the garbage removal staff operate between six o'clock at midnight.
The police had inside knowledge of how the gang operated.

senses.sense: (transitive or intransitive) To produce an appropriate physical effect; to issue in the result designed by nature; especially (medicine) to take appropriate effect on the human system.
(transitive or intransitive) To act or produce effect on the mind; to exert moral power or influence.

(medicine, transitive or intransitive) To perform some manual act upon a human body in a methodical manner, and usually with instruments, with a view to restore soundness or health, as in amputation, lithotomy, etc.
examples: The surgeon had to operate on her heart.
I'm being operated tomorrow.

senses.sense: (transitive or intransitive) To deal in stocks or any commodity with a view to speculative profits.
(transitive or intransitive) To produce, as an effect; to cause.
(transitive or intransitive) To put into, or to continue in, operation or activity; to work.
examples: to operate a machine

(in combination) operated by the means specified e.g. a battery-operated toy
having undergone an operation
Someone who has an operation.

Of, related to, or typical of opera.
examples: The politician's address was so flamboyant as to be operatic.

senses.sense: Alternative form of operatic
In an operatic manner.
exaggerated or overly emotional behaviour; histrionics
In operation; that operates.
examples: Don't touch the operating machinery.

senses.sense: Involved in an operation.
present participle and gerund of operate
The method by which a device performs its function.
examples: It is dangerous to look at the beam of a laser while it is in operation.

senses.sense: The method or practice by which actions are done.
The act or process of operating; agency; the exertion of power, physical, mechanical, or moral.
A planned undertaking.
examples: The police ran an operation to get vagrants off the streets.
The Katrina relief operation was considered botched.

senses.sense: A business or organization.
examples: We run our operation from a storefront.
They run a multinational produce-supply operation.

senses.sense: (medicine) A surgical procedure.
examples: She had an operation to remove her appendix.

senses.sense: (computing, logic, mathematics) A procedure for generating a value from one or more other values (the operands); (mathematics, more formally) a function which maps zero or more (but typically two) operands to a single output value.
examples: The number of operands associated with an operation is called its arity; an operation of arity 2 is called a binary operation.

senses.sense: (military) A military campaign (e.g. Operation Desert Storm)
(obsolete) Effect produced; influence.
Of or relating to operations, especially military operations.
Functioning and ready for use.
Effective or operative.
Determined by means of practical measures.
(sciences) A philosophy that attempts to define all scientific concepts in terms of specified operations or procedures of observation and measurement.
A proponent of operationalism.
Of or pertaining to operationalism.
In an operational manner; in accordance with an operation.
(philosophy) The doctrine that the meaning of a term consists of the operation(s) performed in defining it
A proponent of operationism.
plural of operation
Effectual or important.
examples: He's usually in a good mood — the operative word there being "usually". Today was a disaster.

senses.sense: Functional, in working order.
Having the power of acting; hence, exerting force, physical or moral; active in the production of effects.
examples: an operative motive

senses.sense: Producing the appropriate or designed effect; efficacious.
examples: an operative dose, rule, or penalty

senses.sense: Based upon, or consisting of, a surgical operation or operations. 1

(uncountable) The game of Chinese whispers.
(informal) A person who is adept at making deals or getting results, especially one who uses questionable methods.
A member of a military special operations unit.

(linguistics) A kind of expression that enters into an a-bar movement dependency and is said to bind a variable.
examples: In the sentence "What did Bill say he wants to buy?", "what" is an operator, binding a phonetically empty variable.

senses.sense: Obsolete form of opuscule.
plural of opusculum
A small or petty work.
plural of opuscule
An opuscule; a short work.
plural of opus
